segments.text: to the American consulate, you know, the Hungarian, actually the American consulate in Vienna who was taking care of the Hungarian refugees and then
We got our visas, we got our papers.
They interrogated my father and asked him if he's a communist or not, or if he ever was a communist, which he was a communist because he had two children.
If he wasn't a communist, he wasn't communist at heart, you know, but he had to say he was, otherwise he would never get the kind of treatment that we got, you know.
But anyhow, he convinced the people over there that he wasn't a communist and everything.
So we got sent to Salzburg from there on a train.
And then from Salzburg, we took an electric train all the way across Austria through Germany to Bremenhaven.
Bremen Harbor, it's a big port next to Hamburg, a big seaport, you know.
And on the 19th of January, we took aboard on a military ship.
About 2,000 of us were put on that ship, and then we came, sailed across the United States.
And it took us 11 days, 11 days to get over here.
What were the feelings on the ship?
On the ship, it was wonderful.
Everybody got seasick, though, but, you know, the feeling of the freedom and, you know,
When you get to the New York Harbor and then you sailed across the Statue of Liberty, I mean, you know, my mother was crying and then it was really, really cold.
And I remember the ship was coming in, you know, and then we see this faint light and then we got closer and you saw it was the Statue of Liberty, you know.
It was, the feeling was, you know, just like a rebirth, you know, a renaissance of a new life, you know.
My father and my mother was planning.
And there's a lot of uncertainties also because you didn't know what you were getting into, you know, and you had two young children, you know, that needed taking care of and everything.
So, but they had a lot of ambition, you know, and they were healthy and they knew they could make it in a new world.
And once we got to the harbor, we were here for two days.
They wouldn't let us out of the boat until we went through another total...
examination, medical examination, you know.
And then we were sent to a military post.
We went to Camp Kilmer in New Jersey.
They took us on.
Everybody was put on big buses, about 15, 20 buses, and we all went over there.
And we got a new set of clothing over there.
We were there for about a week, you know.
and a new set of clothing from top to bottom, you know, just everything.
And a religious group from Salem, New Jersey had approached the camp and they were looking for three Hungarian families that they promised work and housing for.
And we happened to be one of the three families and we settled in Phelan, New Jersey in the beginning.
This was from February of 1957 until
August of 69, you know, is when we moved from New Jersey to Texas, you know, but during those years, you know, I went through high school.
I married a Hungarian woman whom I met in a Hungarian church, you know, and in that part of the United States, like in New Jersey, there's a lot of ethnic groups.
Everybody was coming across the Atlantic Ocean from Europe.
There were a lot of

lot of German people, a lot of Hungarian people, a lot of Russians, you know, a lot of Polish people, and they were all had their own little towns in New York City, you know, and we lived only about 10-15 miles from the New York City, and we all went to take get picnics over there.
They had Hungarian schools, Hungarian churches, so
we fit in pretty easy over there and the transition was a little bit easier going through this way.
In the beginning when you first came to the United States did you still hear

keep up of course you did but did you hear all what was going on in Hungary still yes we we did in the beginning we exchanged a lot of letters but the letters got censored and we got the word from our relatives that we should not write or we should break contacts because they made the lives of our loved ones over there a lot harder because

because of our association their association with us so slowly but surely you know we stopped writing letters and uh it was uh it was a sad situation but they they heard us anywhere they could you know so this was one of the ways they did
The early ways of fitting into the new society and the new life was kind of hard.
It wasn't really hard for me.
It was harder for my mother and my father, you know.
I picked up the language real fast.
I remember I went to the first grade and
In that spring of 57, I started the first grade for a couple of weeks.
I learned how to read and write.
I remember correcting the math papers for the little kids.
And then I went from the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, all the way through until sixth or seventh by the end of June.
I was a beginning 10th grader when I left Hungary, and I picked up

10th grade all over again so I really I lost one year along the way but I had a lot of credit they gave me a lot of credit for for foreign language I I had six years of Russian behind me when I was a 10th grader I started Russian they made a start real early you know they didn't they didn't learn too much but they learned

taught us a lot of songs in Russian and learn we learn how to how to count and things like that just just words you know we had to do so it my father started as a painter you know they gave first they they put him into a a machine shop and he couldn't cope with the

the change over from decimal system to the to the inches was very very hard for him he could not he could he couldn't transfer the system over you know so this this Dutch painter this guy came from Holland and he was started to he asked my father if he would go and help him paint you know so I remember my father got
a dollar and a quarter for an hour to paint with him, and then he became a painter from that point on.
He got real good at it, and thus the Nagy and Son, we had a Nagy and Son painting and decorating over there.
I was still young.
I only helped him on the weekends because I was still in school, but I used to go with him and give estimates.
you know, on jobs, and I was driving the truck.
I already got my license when I was, I turned 16.

at June 5th 1957 and I got a license and I helped my father get a license also you know and so he was able to drive fairly soon and re-established our painting business and it flourished and it was pretty good and
I got married in 1964 and in 1969 we left New Jersey because we felt that to raise a family, the state was very crowded and the place where we lived was a very crowded city.
There was, you know, just, you know,
Was the United States like you had, did it turn out to be like you had expected, or from what you had heard?
Well, it turned out much, much more than what I expected.
I have never, I didn't expect anything, what I've got, what I've, you know, I...
I didn't expect paved roads and tall skyscrapers and the quality of life and all that was just a shock to us.
The department stores and the supermarkets just blew my mind because over there you had to stand in line for five pounds of frozen potato, you know, and then
They measured out the flour into a little paper sack that you had to take with you because the grocer didn't have the paper sacks to put the stuff in, you know.
And they had these little carrying bags and then they would dump the tomatoes or the potatoes or the rice or what have you right in your bag, you know.
And over here you go in there and everything is pre-packed and nobody, you just take it from the shelf and go through to the cashier and pay for it and be gone, you know.
And that was just very, you know, the abundance of articles and the clothing, the shoes.
My father had to work an hour for one egg.
You had to work for a whole week for a pair of shoes, you know.

I mean, this is the type, I mean, I had to, I worked a whole summer long, you know, in between school, summer vacations, I used to go work for the railroad, empty car, empty, unload railroad cars, coals and sand, and sometimes the residue from the factory, you know, when they, when they,

When the coal burns, there's a lot of ashes and they put these ashes on the cars and then they carry them out in the suburbs of the cities and then you dump them over there and they spread it out over there between the railroad tracks and stuff.
I did that all summer long.
And I was able to buy a suit of clothing, you know, a pair of pants and a shirt and a pair of shoes, you know.
But these little things helped a great deal because my parents weren't able to, you know, afford too much, you know, just the bare necessities and all these things over here.
When I first came to this country, I got a dictionary, and I said, I'm going to go get a job.
And I was 17 years old.
And I went up and down the street with a dictionary in my hand.
And I went into every store.
I was 16 years old.
I didn't even speak any English.
And I got hired in a Hebrew national.
There's a lot of Jewish people on the East Coast.
And I was working in a delicatessen as a kitchen boy.
I wasn't allowed to go into the store.
I was in the back over there cleaning out the shelves and sweeping up and just general tidying.
And I got $0.70 an hour.
for doing that, and I thought that was just great, you know.
I made more money in one week than my father done in a month.
Yeah, it was great.
So, yeah, that was my first one.
And then I also was a paper boy, and later on when I advanced a little bit in my speech, I worked for a furniture store as a delivery boy, you know, and, you know,
I went through hard times.
After high school, I attended the University of Fairleigh Dickinson for a couple of years.
I attended some courses in Rutgers for a semester and a half, and I never finished college altogether.
was going to finish it.
I finished a trade school called RETS.
It's a radio, electronic, and tech television school, you know.
So I'm a full-fledged, you might call it a mechanical engineer, sort of, you know.
But never finished college.
And when I was...
I got married in 1964, and we lived four more years, and then we decided to come to Texas in 1969.
And ever since, you know, I used to live on Hillview Drive for 17 or 18 years, and then we sold that house over here.
I'm just kind of continuing what I started.
You know, I was a painter, I'm still a painter, but I do some remodeling now.
And I have four children, and we're making it.
Quite well.
Looking back on it, what do you feel are some of the most significant outcomes of the Revolution of 1946?
Well, the most significant outcome of the Revolution, in my mind, was that...
We tried it for a while and it worked for two weeks, you see.
And that put a very big dream in a people's mind, you know.
And as we can see it, that, you know, ever since then there were really little revolutions throughout the areas, you know.

Czechoslovakia had another one in the early 60s and Poland never really gotten really settled Poland was always one that was always dissatisfied and finally I think the whole disillusionment and everything just came to a
such an abrupt end in this last year, you know, that communism just totally got wiped out.
I really like to go back and visit.
Up to now, I was not able to go back because I'm wearing my father's name, you know, I'm junior, and he was really sought after after the revolution.
And later on, in the early days, my relatives wrote that my father would have gotten deported to Siberia had he come back.
Excuse me.
I don't know.
Amnesty rules didn't make any difference over there.
But I'd like to go back now and visit where I grew up and where I went to school.

see if I can locate some of my relatives most of my father's brothers and sisters he had three brothers and a sister they're all died you know so did my father he died 1974 you know over here in Texas but I think it wasn't in vain I don't think it was in vain because you know it it it
Everybody finally got freedom because of some of the peoples, you know.
So what were your feelings when you saw the wall come down?
Oh, boy, I would have loved to be there, you know, because we didn't climb that wall because we didn't come through there.
But the wall to me was coming across the Iron Curtain, you know, and it was up there.
And it was down for two weeks, but after that it was up, you know.
And I was really thrilled when all these things were happening, you know.
I said, my God, if my father would have...
would be alive now.
It was just great.
I really am thankful for this country.
I would go to war for this country, you know, and I would, you know, raise arms and I would defend this country because I think, you know, there's a lot of good, you know, is here, you know.
Freedom is what people want, you know, and it's a very big thing to be cherished.
Well thank you very much for this interview, Mr. Nagy.
You're welcome.
